channel.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
channel.description:
Okay so I have a .rtf document in my project. The Build Action is set to content (When you change the Build Action the Immediate Window produces a different message). The Copy to Output Directory is set to copy always. I have this code:
[code]RichTextBox1.LoadFile("YewScape Command Generator Tutorial.rtf")[/code]
No errors are given but when I get to this point in the code the Immediate Window says this when the Build Action is set to content:
[code]A first chance exception of type 'System.ArgumentException' occurred in System.Windows.Forms.dll[/code]
When it is set to resource:
[code]A first chance exception of type 'System.IO.FileNotFoundException' occurred in mscorlib.dll[/code]
Does anyone know what I'm doing wrong?

item.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

I ended up using the stream reader instead. Thanks for all the help!

Read full topic

item.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:18, topic:346019”]…Davidi2 why are you helping? You hate .NET…

Open your project’s Properties tab (If this still exists in 2010), and add your file into the resources section. To use it, the location is project/namespace name.Properties.Resources.*. That’s it.[/quote]I help anyway

amgz thats almost exactly wut i sed!

Read full topic

item.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
item.dc:creator: @sp11k3t3ht3rd sp11k3t3ht3rd
item.description:
@sp11k3t3ht3rd wrote:

When you set the Copy to Output Directory for the resource to copy always it automatically sends the resource to the debug sub folder in bin. When it run’s then it has the file with it in the debug folder. The file is in my project, It’s in my resources.

Read full topic
item.source: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project

item.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

To what I was thinking, he has it, not in the project folder, but within the “soon to be exe” project itself. Or at least that’s the impression I got when he mentioned resources.

Sorry for the “soon to be exe” part, its a habbit I’ve developed, don’t know where from.

Read full topic
item.source: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project

item.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:8, topic:346019”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=442395.msg3248950#msg3248950 date=1277599849]

It still gives me those two exceptions and doesn’t load the file.
[/quote]Are you sure that you have a valid filename etc?

One way to do this (please ignore CoonHunter’s suggestion) is to go to your Project Properties, go to Resources, ‘Add Resource’ -> New Text File

And then using your RichTextBox do LoadFile(My.Resources.whateveryourfilenamewas.txt)

Let him try putting the RTF he is trying to load where the debugger loads from. I betcha it works, without any code edits from his main code.[/quote]I thought he already had it there…

Sp11k, you have it in your project folder right…

Or you can use it’s absolute path (“C://fbab/faf/d.rtf”) etc

Read full topic

item.title: [Visual Basic 2010 Express Edition] Can't load an .rtf file thats in my project
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

Don’t hold me on this, because I could be wrong, but I don’t believe you can put a RTF file inside of a “soon to be exe” project, and it load. The problem, is when you use:

RichTextBox1.LoadFile("YewScape Command Generator Tutorial.rtf")

It is looking in the EXE’s directory for that file. Not within the EXE, my suggestion, is to just just save it as a string within the EXE, and load it from there.

Read full topic
